articles.title: EU-funded program trains youth as tourist guides of the archaeological park of Bylis in Albania
articles.summary: The aim of the program is to develop the area as a tourist destination with qualified staff, good services, and strong management.
articles.content:
The aim of the program is to develop the area as a tourist destination with qualified staff, good services, and strong management.

With ten centuries of history, from the 4th century BC to the 6th century AD, the hill where the archaeological park of Bylis is located in the Mallakastër area in the southwest of Albania offers a stunning view of the Vjosa River – but there is much more to discover.

Many young people from the area have become part of the training for local tourist guides, as part of the program “EU for Economic Development – Local Economic Development led by tourism, focusing on Cultural Heritage.”

These young people will reveal the secrets of the park to visitors, while also growing professionally themselves.

The project, supported by the EU, works to improve skills and capacities, while simultaneously increasing cooperation between local communities and the park administration.

16 applicants are attending lectures in various modules, learning the history of the area from Professor Neritan Ceka, who has excavated in the park for decades, as well as participating in communication training. The applicants will be certified in November.

The applicants learn the communication module, which covers group management, handling cultural differences, group psychology, public speaking techniques, and guidelines on what a guide should and should not do, whether in an archaeological site, on a walking tour, in a museum, or in a moving vehicle.

According to the team leader, Ilir Parangoni, “EU for Economic Development – Local Economic Development led by tourism, focusing on Cultural Heritage,” is built on three main pillars.

“The first is the preservation of the cultural heritage of the park, which includes the areas of Bylis and Klos. The second is the improvement of tourist infrastructure. The third – and most important – is the economic development of the local community. This pillar includes a wide range of local development initiatives, starting with training young people from the community as guides,” says Parangoni.

The project’s work with the park began with the drafting of key documents, including a management plan and legal frameworks. It is now moving forward with plans to establish a visitor center, information panels, a museum, a community corner, and trails within the Bylis Park.

The goal is to develop the area as a tourist destination with qualified staff, good services, and strong management.

Local artisanal products will have their own space, and the program aims to highlight what is authentic in the area – from traditional recipes to embroidery.

Although the applicants have lived in the area since they were young, they are now becoming aware of the many opportunities it offers, with cultural, historical, natural, and industrial tourism.

“EU for Economic Development – Local Economic Development led by tourism, focusing on Cultural Heritage” is a project funded by the EU and implemented by AICS, which aims to increase and preserve the usability and attractiveness of cultural heritage assets at the archaeological site of Bylis.

The program preserves and restores the cultural heritage of Bylis, improves access, and increases the sustainability of the cultural heritage of Bylis, natural assets, and other local assets with the participation and inclusion of local communities. It also promotes local economic development through the adoption of the EU’s Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) approach, improving skills and capacities, as well as increasing cooperation between local communities and the park administration. (September 29)

articles.personality_title: Young Albanians trained as guides to share Bylis archaeological park’s history
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The archaeological park of Bylis in southwest Albania holds ruins dating back over 1,500 years. This site near the Vjosa River is rich in history but has not yet fully developed as a tourist destination.

**What happened** – An EU-funded program started training 16 local young people to become official tourist guides for the park. They attend lessons on the park’s history, taught by expert archaeologist Neritan Ceka, and take communication classes to learn how to lead groups and speak confidently to visitors. The trainees will receive certification in November.

**Impact** – This program helps protect Bylis’s cultural heritage by teaching young locals about its importance and making them ambassadors for their region. It also improves local skills and supports the community’s economy by creating tourism jobs. Plans include building visitor centers, museums, and trails, plus spaces for local crafts and traditional foods.

**What’s next step** – After the guides are certified, they will start working with visitors to share the park’s stories. The project will continue developing infrastructure and services to attract more tourists, further boosting the local economy and preserving cultural treasures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Training young locals as guides is helping turn Bylis archaeological park into a well-managed tourist site that benefits both visitors and the community.
articles.personality_title_fr: De jeunes Albanais formés comme guides pour partager l’histoire du parc archéologique de Bylis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le parc archéologique de Bylis, dans le sud-ouest de l’Albanie, abrite des ruines datant de plus de 1 500 ans. Ce site près de la rivière Vjosa est riche en histoire mais n’est pas encore pleinement développé comme destination touristique.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un programme financé par l’UE a commencé à former 16 jeunes locaux pour devenir guides touristiques officiels du parc. Ils suivent des cours sur l’histoire du site, enseignée par l’archéologue expert Neritan Ceka, et des formations en communication pour apprendre à diriger des groupes et parler avec assurance aux visiteurs. Les stagiaires seront certifiés en novembre.

**Impact** – Ce programme aide à protéger le patrimoine culturel de Bylis en enseignant aux jeunes locaux son importance et en faisant d’eux des ambassadeurs de leur région. Il améliore aussi les compétences locales et soutient l’économie communautaire en créant des emplois liés au tourisme. Des projets incluent la construction de centres d’accueil, musées, sentiers, ainsi que des espaces pour l’artisanat local et la cuisine traditionnelle.

**Étape suivante** – Une fois certifiés, les guides commenceront à accompagner les visiteurs pour raconter l’histoire du parc. Le projet continuera à développer les infrastructures et services pour attirer plus de touristes, renforçant ainsi l’économie locale et préservant les trésors culturels.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Former des jeunes locaux comme guides aide à faire du parc archéologique de Bylis un site touristique bien géré qui profite aux visiteurs et à la communauté.
articles.personality_title_es: Jóvenes albaneses capacitados como guías para compartir la historia del parque arqueológico de Bylis
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El parque arqueológico de Bylis, en el suroeste de Albania, contiene ruinas que datan de hace más de 1.500 años. Este sitio junto al río Vjosa es muy histórico pero aún no está completamente desarrollado como destino turístico.

**Qué pasó** – Un programa financiado por la UE comenzó a entrenar a 16 jóvenes locales para que sean guías turísticos oficiales del parque. Reciben clases sobre la historia del lugar, impartidas por el arqueólogo experto Neritan Ceka, y entrenamiento en comunicación para aprender a dirigir grupos y hablar con confianza a los visitantes. Los participantes serán certificados en noviembre.

**Impacto** – Este programa ayuda a proteger el patrimonio cultural de Bylis al enseñar a los jóvenes locales su valor y convertirlos en embajadores de su región. También mejora las habilidades locales y apoya la economía comunitaria al crear empleos en turismo. Hay planes para construir centros de visitantes, museos, senderos y espacios para artesanías y comidas tradicionales.

**Próximo paso** – Tras la certificación, los guías comenzarán a trabajar con visitantes para contar las historias del parque. El proyecto seguirá desarrollando infraestructuras y servicios para atraer más turistas, impulsando la economía local y preservando los tesoros culturales.

**Frase clave** – Capacitar a jóvenes locales como guías está ayudando a convertir el parque arqueológico de Bylis en un sitio turístico bien gestionado que beneficia tanto a visitantes como a la comunidad.
